content: Chapter 154 of Title 28, United States Code, introduces special habeas corpus procedures in capital cases. Chapter 154 of Title 28, United States Code, introduces special habeas corpus procedures in capital cases. This chapter applies to cases under section 2254 brought by prisoners in State custody subject to a capital sentence, with specific requirements for appointment of counsel. The chapter introduces special habeas corpus procedures in capital cases, including the appointment, compensation, and reimbursement of competent counsel for indigent prisoners with upheld capital convictions. The mechanism must offer counsel to all state prisoners under a capital sentence and provide standards of competency for their appointment. The chapter outlines procedures for appointing competent counsel for indigent prisoners with upheld capital convictions. Counsel appointed must not have represented the prisoner previously at trial or on direct appeal unless requested. Ineffectiveness of counsel during post-conviction proceedings is not grounds for relief. Mandatory stays of execution are also discussed. The chapter outlines procedures for appointing competent counsel for indigent prisoners with upheld capital convictions. A stay of execution for a State prisoner can be granted upon application to the court with jurisdiction over section 2254 proceedings, if post-conviction review procedures have been invoked. The stay expires if the prisoner fails to file a habeas corpus petition within the required time or if relief is denied after district court and court of appeals review under section 2254. The chapter outlines procedures for appointing competent counsel for indigent prisoners with upheld capital convictions. If certain conditions are met, no Federal court can grant a stay of execution or relief in a capital case unless specific criteria are fulfilled, such as presenting a new claim not previously raised in State or Federal courts. The district court must assess the sufficiency of the evidentiary record based on claims presented in State courts, unless there was a failure to raise a claim due to State action violating the Constitution or laws of the United States. The district court must conduct any necessary evidentiary hearings to complete the record for habeas corpus review. Upon the development of a complete evidentiary record, the court will rule on the merits of the claims. The requirement of a certificate of probable cause does not apply to habeas corpus cases subject to this chapter, except for second or successive petitions.
